summary: Nikolay Sergeyevich Leonov was a KGB officer who supported Latin American revolutionary activities, particularly in Guatemala. He later became Chief of Service No. 1 (Information) of KGB Headquarters First (Foreign Intelligence) Directorate in Moscow. Documents also detail his activities and surveillance, particularly his connections with Fidel Castro. Reports detail their interactions, Leonov's movements, and related intelligence assessments. He was active in the 1960s and 1970s.
significance: The documents suggest Leonov was a significant figure in Soviet intelligence operations in Latin America during the Cold War. While the documents do not directly link Leonov to the JFK assassination, his role as a high-ranking KGB officer with connections to Fidel Castro, who had motives to retaliate against the US, could be of interest in the context of investigating potential foreign involvement in the assassination. The surveillance of other Soviet officials in Mexico City, such as Loginov, adds another layer of complexity.
